document.docAuthor: Nicholls, James A., Stone, Graham N. & Melika, George
document.docTitle: Protobalandricus spectabilis Nicholls & Stone & Melika 2018, new comb.
document.masterDocTitle: A new genus of oak gallwasp, Protobalandricus Melika, Nicholls & Stone (Hymenoptera: Cynipidae: Cynipini) from California

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A new genus of oak gallwasp, Protobalandricus Melika, Nicholls & Stone (Hymenoptera: Cynipidae: Cynipini) from California

subSubSection.paragraph:
Andricus spectabilis Kinsey, 1922
.
Disholcaspis spectabilis ( Melika & Abrahamson 2002 )
.

Types are deposited at the AMNH , NYC and labeled as ”Pasadena Cal., Gall 2.7.20 .”, ”
Q. chrysolepis , Kinsey
coll.”, red ”
Andricus spectabilis
, Holotype ”. The holotype and seven female paratypes in the general collection with the same labels as the holotype were examined. Details of adults reared by the authors are given below in “Material examined”.
Diagnosis. Morphological peculiarities of the species are given in the Diagnosis to the genus above.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 17–22.
Holocynips hartmani
, asexual female: 17, head, frontal view. 18, antenna. 19, mesosoma and propleura, frontal view. 20, mesosoma, dorsal view. 21, metascutellum and propodeum, posterodorsal view. 22, metasoma, lateral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description. A detailed description of the species is given in Kinsey (1922a , 1922b ),
Liljeblad et al . (2008)
, also see the genus description above.

Material examined.
“ USA , CA, Berry Summit , east of Arcata ( 40.87° N , 123.73° W )
,
leg. J. Nicholls , 2007.11.0 4., ex
Quercus vacciniifolia
”, “ USA , CA, Irvine Lodge picnic area ( 39.58° N , 123.45° W )
,
leg. J. Nicholls , 2007.11.0 3., ex
Quercus chrysolepis
”; “ USA , CA, 12 km NE of Angels Camp ( 38.15° N , 120.44° W )
,
leg. J. Nicholls , 2008.0 3.29., ex
Quercus chrysolepis ”
; “ USA , CA, Shiell Gulch campground ( 40.47° N , 123.06° W )
,
leg. J. Nicholls , 2008.0 4.0 1., ex
Quercus chrysolepis
”; “ USA , CA, Highway 33, Los Padres National Forest ( 34.64° N , 119.38° W )
,
leg. J. DeMartini , 2006.10.20., ex
Quercus chrysolepis
”; “ USA , CA, Yosemite National Park ( 37.75° N , 119.60° W )
, leg. P. Fuentes-Utrilla, 2010.0 2.0 5., ex
Quercus chrysolepis
”. 22 females were reared from the collected galls.

Variation. The metasoma of
P. spectabilis
varies in coloration, with reddish brown and dark chestnut brown forms. However, both color variants can be found among females reared from the same site, for example in our series from Irvine Lodge picnic area and Shiell Gulch campground. Kinsey (1922b) described two varieties:
A. spectabilis var. ukiahensis
, and
A. spectabilis var. incisus
, types of which are deposited at the AMNH, NYC. We examined both: for
spectabilis var. ukiahensis
—female labeled as ”Ukiah, Cal., Gall 3.14.20 .”, ”
Q. chrysolepis , Kinsey
coll.”, red ”
A. ukiahensis
, Holo- COTYPE” and seven female paratypes in the general collection with the same labels as the holotype; for
spectabilis var. incisus
—
female labeled as ”Placerville, 3.30.20 . Cal., gall 3.30.20 .”, ”
Q. chrysolepis , Kinsey
coll.”, pink ”
A. incisus
, Holo-COTYPE” and seven female paratypes in the general collection with the same labels as the holotype. Kinsey’s varieties,
spectabilis var. incisus
and
spectabilis var. ukiahensis
, differ from
spectabilis
only by the reddish brown metasoma, otherwise the morphology is the same as that of
A. spectabilis .
Thus,
Andricus spectabilis var. incisus Kinsey, 1922
and
Andricus spectabilis var. ukiahensis
are syn. nova of
Protobalandricus spectabilis (Kinsey)
,
new comb.

Gall ( Figs 15–16 ). Elongated multilocular stem swelling gall, oval to spindle-shaped, 25 mm broad, up to 55–100 mm long, surface covered by bark with the same colour and texture as the bark of twigs. While growing the gall tissues have the texture of firm cheese and can easily be cut; when mature, the gall is woody and hard internally. Larval chambers are 3 mm in diameter, up to 5 mm long and usually located towards the center of the gall.

Biology. Only the asexual generation is known. The gall was previously known only from
Quercus chrysolepis
. We also collected this species from
Q. vacciniifolia Kellogg. Galls
develop in late summer/autumn and are mature by October-November. Adults overwinter in the galls and emerge in the following spring.

Distribution . Currently known only from California USA . According to Govaerts & Frodin (1998) , the host plant
Q. chrysolepis
is found in the USA in California , western Oregon , Arizona , south Nevada , and
New
Mexico
, and in
Mexico
it is recorded from
Baja California
and NW Chihuahua . The other host plant,
Q. vacciniifolia ,
is found in California , southwestern Oregon and western Nevada . During 2007-2009 the authors sampled many sites across California and Arizona where one or other of the host plants were present, but
P. spectabilis
was only found in California .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 23–29.
Andricus quercuscalifornicus
, asexual female: 23–24, head: 23, frontal view, 24, posterior view. 25–27, mesosoma: 25, dorsal view, 26, dorsal view, anterior part, 27, lateral view. 28, metascutellum and propodeum, posterodorsal view. 29, metasoma, lateral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Comments. Within-species variation in cytb is high, with sequences clustering into two mitochondrial lineages that show limited diversity within lineages (0% and 0.9% among three and four individuals per lineage respectively), but a divergence of 10.4-10.9% between individuals from different lineages. This variation is much higher than that typically seen within cynipid species (e.g.
Nicholls et al . 2012
;
Tang et al . 2016a
, 2016b ). The two cytb lineages do not correspond to the observed morphological variation in the colour of the metasoma; instead the mitochondrial lineages are spatially structured, with one lineage sampled only from Los Padres National Forest in southern California , and the other from sites in northern California . However, this deep divergence in the mitochondrial data is not reflected in the nuclear ITS2 data, with only limited variation apparent among the seven sequences obtained (3 variable sites out of 606 base pairs, 0.5%), consistent with expected within-species diversity at this locus (
Nicholls et al . 2012
). Although limited, the variation in ITS 2 may also possibly reflect spatial structure, with two variable sites separating the sample from Yosemite National Park from the other samples, and one variable site separating the southern Californian samples from the remainder. These genetic results indicate that
P. spectabilis
is a single coherent species that nevertheless shows significant population structure, perhaps reflecting refugial structure from Pleistocene climate oscillations.
